contentrichtext.text: [[File:Earth poster.svg|350px|thumb|The structure of the Earth]] The '''outer core''' of the [[Earth]] is a liquid layer about {{convert|2266|km|mi|abbr=on}} thick composed of [[iron]] and [[nickel]] which lies above the Earth's solid [[inner core]] and below its [[mantle (geology)|mantle]]. Its outer boundary lies {{convert|2890|km|mi|abbr=on}} beneath the Earth's surface. The transition between the inner core and outer core is located approximately {{convert|5150|km|mi|abbr=on}} beneath the Earth's surface. ==Properties== The temperature of the outer core ranges from 4400 °C (8000 °F) in the outer regions to 6100 °C (11000 °F) near the inner core. Because of its high temperature, modeling work has shown that the outer core is a low [[viscosity]] fluid (about ten times the viscosity of liquid metals at the surface) that convects [[turbulence|turbulently]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=The viscosity of liquid iron at the physical conditions of the Earth's core|doi=10.1038/33905|url=http://www.homepages.ucl.ac.uk/~ucfbdxa/pubblicazioni/nat.pdf| volume=392 | issue=6678|year=1998|last1=Gillan|first1=Michael J.|last2=De Wijs|first2=Gilles iA.|last3=Kresse|first3=Georg|last4=Vočadlo|first4=Lidunka|last5=Dobson|first5=David|last6=Alfè|first6=Dario|last7=Price|first7=Geoffrey D.|journal=Nature|pages=805|bibcode = 1998Natur.392..805D }}</ref> [[Eddy current]]s in the nickel iron [[fluid]] of the outer core are believed to influence the [[Earth's magnetic field]]. The average [[magnetic field]] strength in the Earth's outer core was measured to be 25 gauss, 50 times stronger than the magnetic field at the surface.<ref>[http://www.science20.com/news_articles/first_measurement_magnetic_field_inside_earths_core First Measurement Of Magnetic Field Inside Earth's Core]. Science20.com. Retrieved on 2012-01-27.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1038/nature09643|title=Tidal dissipation and the strength of the Earth's internal magnetic field|year=2010|last1=Buffett|first1=Bruce A.|journal=Nature|volume=468|issue=7326|pages=952–4|pmid=21164483|bibcode = 2010Natur.468..952B }}</ref> The outer core is not under enough pressure to be solid, so it is liquid even though it has a composition similar to that of the inner core. [[Sulfur]] and [[oxygen]] could also be present in the outer core.<ref name=nature473_361>{{Cite journal | first1=David | last1=Gubbins | first2=Binod | last2=Sreenivasan | first3=Jon | last3=Mound | first4=Sebastian | last4=Rost | title=Melting of the Earth's inner core | journal=Nature | volume=473 | pages=361–363 | date=May 19, 2011 | doi=10.1038/nature10068 | issue=7347 | pmid=21593868 |bibcode = 2011Natur.473..361G }}</ref> As heat is transferred outward toward the [[Mantle (geology)|mantle]], the net trend is for the inner boundary of the liquid region to freeze, causing the solid inner core to grow. This growth rate is estimated to be 1 mm per year.<ref name=ng4_264>{{cite journal| title=Reconciling the hemispherical structure of Earth's inner core with its super-rotation | first1=Lauren | last1=Waszek | first2=Jessica | last2=Irving | first3=Arwen | last3=Deuss | journal=Nature Geoscience | volume=4 | pages=264–267 | doi=10.1038/ngeo1083 | year=2011| issue=4 |bibcode = 2011NatGe...4..264W }}</ref> ==Effect on life== Without the outer core, life on Earth would be very different. Convection of liquid metals in the outer core creates the [[Earth's magnetic field]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://woodrowshew.com/pepi05.pdf |author=Woodrow L. Shew, Daniel P. Lathrop |title=Liquid sodium model of geophysical core convection |journal=Physics of the Earth and Planetary Interiors |volume=153 |year=2005 |pages=136–149|doi=10.1016/j.pepi.2005.03.013|bibcode = 2005PEPI..153..136S }}</ref><ref>Kent C. Condie, ''Plate Tectonics,'' Butterworth-Heinemann; 4th ed., 1997, p. 140 ISBN 978-0-7506-3386-4</ref> This magnetic field extends outward from the Earth for several thousand kilometers, and creates a protective bubble around the Earth that deflects the [[solar wind]]. Without this field, a larger proportion of the solar wind would directly strike the Earth's atmosphere. The presumed effect would be to strip the [[Earth's atmosphere]] away slowly. This is hypothesized to have happened to the [[Mars|Martian]] atmosphere, rendering the planet incapable of supporting life.<ref>[http://scign.jpl.nasa.gov/learn/plate1.htm Structure of the Earth]. Scign.jpl.nasa.gov. Retrieved on 2012-01-27.</ref> ==See also== * [[SKS wave]] * [[Structure of the Earth]] ==References== {{reflist|35em}} ==External links== * [http://www.universetoday.com/guide-to-space/earth/earths-outer-core/ Outer core from universetoday.com] {{earth}} {{earthsinterior}} [[Category:Structure of the Earth]] [[Category:Geomagnetism]]
